bestBHT.bht: Paul declares that his boasting is rooted in the genuine work of Christ through him, specifically in bringing the Gentiles to obedience through his preaching and actions. He acknowledges that without Christ's involvement, he would not dare to speak or go beyond what Christ has accomplished. Paul attributes all his success to the active work of the living Redeemer, emphasizing the importance of the Spirit's power in his preaching and mighty signs and wonders. His ultimate purpose is to give glory to God for the obedience of the Gentiles, achieved through the Spirit's empowerment.

Henry Alford: I have real ground for glorying."
I will only boast of what Christ has veritably done by me towards the obedience of the Gentiles."
I have fully preached (literally, fulfilled) the Gospel of Christ.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: I will not dare to speak of any - to speak aught.
I will not dare to go beyond what Christ hath wrought by me.
Paul ascribes all the success of his labors to the activity of the living Redeemer, working in and by him.
Albert Barnes: I should be restrained; I should be afraid to speak if the thing were not as I have stated."
I confine myself 'strictly' to what I have done."
The 'deeds,' that is, the 'lives' of Christian ministers are often as efficacious in bringing people to Christ as their public ministry.
John Calvin: He at last concludes with this expression, through the power of the Spirit; by which he intimates that these things could not have been done without the Spirit being the author.
In short, he declares that with regard to his teaching as well as his doing, he had such strength and energy in preaching Christ, that it was evidently the wonderful power of God.
This is a striking passage respecting the benefit of miracles: they are designed to prepare men to reverence and to obey God.
Philip Schaff: I will speak boldly, have my ground of glorying, only in such things as Christ wrought through me.
Unto the obedience of the Gentiles, with this design and result, that they became obedient to Christ by believing in Him.
'Word' refers to his preaching; 'deed' includes all the other labors of his apostolic activity.
Archibald T. Robertson: Any one of those things which Christ did not work through me.
John Gill: what he had wrought, and which he could with good conscience speak of to the honour of Christ, and the glory of his grace, were not wrought by himself, but what Christ wrought by him
The Gospel was sent among them, and was blessed unto them, to make them, of disobedient, obedient ones
by the former is meant, the word of the Gospel and the preaching of it, being sent unto them, and coming with power, and not as the word of man, but as the word of God
John Wesley: By word — By the power of the Spirit.
By deed — Namely, through "mighty signs and wonders.

bhtAttempts.bht: Paul declares that he will only boast about what Christ has truly accomplished through him, specifically in bringing the Gentiles to obedience through words and actions. He acknowledges that without the active involvement of Christ, he would not dare to speak or exceed beyond what Christ has done. Furthermore, Paul attributes all his success to the active work of the living Redeemer, emphasizing the importance of the Spirit's power in his preaching and the signs and wonders performed. Overall, Paul's focus is on giving glory to God for the obedience of the Gentiles, achieved through the power of the Spirit in his preaching and miraculous deeds.

Paul acknowledges that his boasting is grounded in the true work of Christ through him, specifically in bringing the Gentiles to obedience through preaching and exemplary behavior. He humbly recognizes that without Christ's active involvement, he would not dare to speak beyond what Christ has accomplished. Paul attributes all success to the living Redeemer working in and through him, emphasizing the Spirit's power in his words and deeds, including the preaching of the Gospel and the performance of miracles. Ultimately, Paul's goal is to give glory to God for the obedience of the Gentiles, achieved through the Spirit's empowerment.

Paul is adamant about boasting only in what Christ has truly done through him, specifically in bringing the Gentiles to obedience through preaching and living out the Gospel. He recognizes that without Christ's involvement, he wouldn't dare to speak or exceed beyond what Christ has accomplished. Paul credits all his success to the active work of the living Redeemer, highlighting the importance of the Spirit's power in his preaching and the miraculous signs and wonders performed. Ultimately, Paul's purpose is to give glory to God for the obedience of the Gentiles, accomplished through the Spirit's empowerment.

Paul humbly asserts that his boasting is firmly grounded in the genuine work of Christ through him, especially in bringing the Gentiles to obedience through both his spoken words and diligent actions. He acknowledges that without Christ's active involvement, he would never dare to speak or go beyond the bounds of what Christ has accomplished. Paul attributes all his achievements to the living Redeemer, underscoring the vital role of the Spirit's power in both his preaching and the remarkable signs and wonders. Ultimately, Paul's ultimate focus is on bringing glory to God for the Gentiles' obedience, achieved through the empowering work of the Spirit.

Paul declares that his boasting is rooted in the genuine work of Christ through him, specifically in bringing the Gentiles to obedience through his preaching and actions. He acknowledges that without Christ's involvement, he would not dare to speak or go beyond what Christ has accomplished. Paul attributes all his success to the active work of the living Redeemer, emphasizing the importance of the Spirit's power in his preaching and mighty signs and wonders. His ultimate purpose is to give glory to God for the obedience of the Gentiles, achieved through the Spirit's empowerment.
